{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3423986,"name":"Greg","username":"Aree_Vanier","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aree_vanier/{size}/129629_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-16T00:34:52.743Z","cooked":"

I was dusting off our robot in preparation of a demo, and I noticed that one of our SparkMaxes was blinking blue instead of cyan. Since this would indicate driving a Neo in brushed mode, I checked the code to make sure everything was correct.

However, the code showed a proper brushless setup. I checked through the hardware client and API, and based on everything I can read from the controller, it is in brushless mode, and the LED colour is incorrect.

Has anyone here seen something similar? Unfortunately the controller is mounted in a way that would require major disassembly to replace it, so I’m hoping to avoid it if possible.

Since I haven’t been in the pit much this year, it’s possible the issue has been present for events/demos and either not damaged the motor, or due to serious overgearing we just never noticed.

image1920×1278 97.7 KB

Behaviour/Testing Steps

When I turn the robot on, the SMax blinks magenta, as all of our controllers are flashed to brushless coast. When the code startup finishes the one in question goes to blue, while all other brake controllers go to cyan as expected.

Since I was unable to directly access the USB port, I queried what data I could from the hardware client over CAN. This allowed me to confirm that the controller is reporting in brushless/brake mode, is running the latest firmware (24.0.1), and has no faults. This matches the neighbouring controller which is blinking cyan.

Switching the controller between coast and brake modes caused the LED to alternate blue/magenta, further hinting that this is an issue with the LED.

I also pulled some general diagnostic data from all of the sparkmaxes from the API in code, and nothing looked out of place.

Diagnostics from all SMaxes

The motor controller in question is ID 8.

ID Motor Type Idle Mode Firmware Fault Sticky Fault Bus Volts
1 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 11.953125
2 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 12.125
3 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 11.953125
4 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 11.9375
5 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 12.0546875
6 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 11.9375
7 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 11.8984375
8 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 12.71875
9 kBrushless kBrake v24.0.1 0 0 12.0078125
10 kBrushless kCoast v24.0.1 -32768 -32768 11.8984375
11 kBrushless kCoast v24.0.1 0 0 11.9296875

(From what I can tell, the fault on SMax 10 is because it’s resting on the limit switch)

I also observed that when blinking that controller (and only that controller), it would cause yellow blinks and CAN Faults on some other controllers on the bus, while it showed solid magenta. Not sure if this is related/notable, since the API data polled earlier didn’t show the sticky CAN faults.

Below gif shows blinking ID8 (left) with ID9 (right) showing yellow, then immediately blinking ID9 with expected behaviour.

Thanks,
Greg

Are you sure thats blue and not cyan? If so it would just be the difference between brake and coast

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-09-16T01:20:50.119Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":31.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":471282,"topic_slug":"sparkmax-led-incorrect-colour","display_username":"Levi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49892,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5690AM | https://lumynlabs.com"},"post_url":"/t/sparkmax-led-incorrect-colour/471282/2","custom_user_title":"5690AM | https://lumynlabs.com","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3424008,"name":"Greg","username":"Aree_Vanier","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aree_vanier/{size}/129629_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-16T01:28:35.301Z","cooked":"

It’s a shade darker than the cyan next to it.

I just quickly checked, and cycling between brushed/brake and brushless/brake shows the same shade of blue (while brushed/cost => brushless/coast does change colour). Definitely a test I should’ve run earlier though.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-09-16T01:28:35.301Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":135,"readers_count":134,"score":32.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":471282,"topic_slug":"sparkmax-led-incorrect-colour","display_username":"Greg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49892,"username":"nobody5690","name":"Levi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nobody5690/{size}/203585_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33581,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Greg (I'll change username eventually) | 2708 -- Alum/Mentor| Programming/Strategy/Scouting"},"post_url":"/t/sparkmax-led-incorrect-colour/471282/3","custom_user_title":"Greg (I'll change username eventually) | 2708 -- Alum/Mentor| Programming/Strategy/Scouting","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3424131,"name":"Brutick","username":"Brutick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/brutick/{size}/198004_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-16T13:32:19.710Z","cooked":"

I have seen this behaviour before (from your video). In my experience, this has been due to intermittent connection on the Spark MAX to either the CAN network or the encoder. My guess is that either one of the JST connectors is loose, or one of the wires inside those connectors is breaking/broken.

Hope this helps.

Ah yeah that would make sense, the placement is tight so it’s quite possible the wires on either end are a bit unhappy (and I do think I saw some intermittent CAN warnings for that SMax).

I will recommend a dissasembly to service them then if we see any issues between now and STEMley.

Thanks!
